episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:

episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back

This decision turned a bold political promise to reach the Moon into an engineering roadmap, stitching together thousands of parts, people, and calculations into a single launch system capable of flinging humans into deep space.

published.fact_text: In 1909, Ernest Shackleton’s Nimrod Expedition turned back just 97 nautical miles from the South Pole, after planting the British flag at the furthest south any human had ever reached. Rather than push on and risk death, Shackleton chose the lives of his crew over glory, redefining heroism in exploration as knowing when to retreat.

published.fact_text: In 1992, astronomers Aleksander Wolszczan and Dale Frail announced the first confirmed discovery of planets outside our Solar System—two worlds orbiting a rapidly spinning dead star, a pulsar called PSR 1257+12. These "pulsar planets" proved that planetary systems could exist in places once thought utterly hostile, opening the floodgates to the modern exoplanet revolution.

Early exposures could take minutes, so bustling streets appeared eerily empty—except for the rare person who stood still long enough to become one of history’s first photographic ghosts.
